resource.chars:
Plate IV

Structures of Disks, chiefly of Complex Type, as <s>seen</s> shown
by horizontal sections.

1. Surface of a disk, whose outer layer, composed of nearly
square closed cells, has been partly ground-away, so as
to lay open the columnar cells of the intermediate layer:-
24 diam.
2. Horizontal section of the intermediate layer, passing (in
consequence of the flexure of the disk, through two diffe-
rent planes, and thus showing the two different direc-
tions of the oblique passages which connect columnar cells of
different zones; also showing a marked difference in
the size of adjacent cells:- 100 diam.
3. Horizontal section of the intermediate layer, immedi-
ately beneath the floors of the superficial cells, <s>showing</s> laying open
the annular canals, with the summits of the colum-
nar cells:- 100 diam.
4. Nucleus and surrounding zones of a disk of simple type, somewhat eccentri-
cally developed; the beak-like projections at each side of
the pores opening into the new zones (shown in Fig. 11)
